title: 108_hr5375
content: The Act may be cited as the "United Nations Accountability Act of 2004". The United Nations Oil-for-Food program faced allegations of mismanagement, fraud, and corruption. Audits by the United Nations Office of Internal Oversight Services revealed mismanagement in contracts for inspection services in Iraq. The audits concluded that the management of the contracts was inadequate and certain provisions were not followed. The United Nations Office of Internal Oversight Services found that the management of contracts for inspection services in Iraq was inadequate. The contractor failed to maintain required staffing levels, overcharged the UN, and engaged in unprofessional conduct. The UN Office of Iraq Programs lacked proper contract management and oversight. The United Nations Office of Iraq Programs lacked proper contract management and oversight, leading to concerns about services provided not aligning with contract terms. The United Nations has a policy of not sharing audit reports with member states, denying the United States access to audits of the Oil-for-Food Program despite repeated requests. This lack of transparency hinders member states' ability to fulfill their responsibilities in UN programs. SEC. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY MEASURES FOR THE UNITED NATIONS. SEC. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY MEASURES FOR THE UNITED NATIONS. Congress urges the President to ensure that all OIOS reports are shared with member states without modification. The Department of State must report on financial disclosure rules for UN officials within 180 days. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to the Oil-for-food program and the Office of Internal Oversight Services established by the United Nations. The curr_chunk explains the term "appropriate congressional committees" as specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate.
